ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DENGUE FEVER



    1. Mr Harun A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment how was the situation of dengue fever in 1998; how effective was the Aedes mosquito campaign and whether it was better than 1997's and, if not, what measures are being taken by his Ministry.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the number of dengue fever cases continued to rise to a record high of 5,258 in 1998. Almost all the cases were the milder dengue fever and not dengue haemorrhagic fever. There was also an increase in the Aedes mosquito house-index, which is a measure of the incidence of breedings detected in homes. The index rose from 1.03 in 1997 to 1.24 in 1998.

    A survey conducted by my Ministry showed that our public education programme on dengue has succeeded in alerting the public but it has not changed their habits generally. Many know that the Aedes mosquito transmits dengue fever

Column: 986

and the conditions under which the Aedes mosquito breeds. However, many admitted that they do not carry out checks routinely in their homes. And this is where the problem lies.

    We will continue with the public education and strict enforcement actions. We will bring the campaign down to the Town Councils and work closely with them.

HAWKER STALLHOLDERS AND RESTAURANT OWNERS

(Suspension from businesses)



    2. Mr Harun A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment how many hawker stallholders and restaurant owners were suspended from their businesses in 1997 and 1998; and how many of them were repeat offenders.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, in 1997, my Ministry suspended the licences of 10 hawker stallholders, 37 restaurant owners and 2 stallholders in coffeeshops. In 1998, the corresponding numbers were 22, 31 and 22 respectively. There was only one licensee, a hawker stallholder, who was suspended twice. The first suspension was for two weeks and the second for four weeks.

Column: 986

HAWKER STALLS
(Reduction of rent)


    3. Mr Harun A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment whether he will consider reducing the rent for hawker stalls during the current economic downturn.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the majority of hawker stalls (14,814) are already paying subsidised rentals, which are well below current market rates. However, there are some 1,600 stallholders who are paying market rentals. These are those who have secured their stalls through public tender or through transfers approved by my Ministry. For these stalls that are charged market rentals, the Government had, with effect from 1st July 1998, reduced the rents by 10%. In January 1999, the rents were reviewed again. For those whose rents were still higher than the market

Column: 987

rental, as assessed by the Chief Valuer as at 1st January 1999, the rent was reduced to 90% of the previous rent or the assessed market rent, whichever is higher. The revised rentals are valid up to 31st December 1999.

    Head J (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [16th March, 1999],

    "That the total sum be allocated for Head J of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr S. Vasoo].

    Question again proposed.

    The Chairman: Head J - Ministry of Community Development. Amendment No. (1), Mr Abdullah Tarmugi.

    The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Sir, allow me to reply to the rest of the Members' amendments raised yesterday.

    Dr Michael Lim observed that a significant number of BASCs have had to be closed down and, according to him, part of the problem was that the facilities are planned centrally by MCD. I wish to assure Members of this House that MCD works closely with community and grassroots organisations in planning social services in HDB estates, including the BASCs. While MCD does the overall planning to ensure a good distribution of facilities, grassroots leaders and the CDCs are briefed on its social services development

Column: 988

master plan to share with them the planning considerations and criteria, the location of these social services and obtain feedback to refine our planning process. We can fine-tune this process further.

    Let me turn to the Member's comment that a number of BASCs have closed down. To-date, we know that three BASCs have closed down, out of about 200 BASCs in Singapore. Two were due to poor demand and the other was affected by upgrading works. BASCs are, like other facilities, developed through the process of consultation which I mentioned earlier. While the number of BASCs to be developed is centrally planned, MCD works closely with theVWOs and grassroots organisations and advisors concerned when determining their location. BASCs run by private operators or those by VWOs that do not require Government funding, do not require any prior endorsement by my Ministry. In such cases, the decisions are made by the organisations concerned based on their commercial consideration. They make their own choices and decisions and therefore they may have to close if they get their sums wrong.

    Let me now turn to Mr Sin Boon Ann's amendment. There are 54 voluntary welfare organisations supported by the Community Chest. MOH, MCD and the Ministry of Education also fund voluntary welfare organisations. Programmes of the organisations that receive public funds are assessed vigorously before they are funded to ensure viability and efficient use of resources. All public funds and donations are audited. VWOs are also registered under the Societies Act or with the Registry of Companies and Businesses, which require them to keep proper accounts and records of their income and expenditure. Their accounts are audited and submitted to the relevant authorities and donors can see these accounts which are also published in their annual reports. Organisations that raise money directly from the public are required to apply to, and follow the guidelines on fund-raising drawn up by, the Licensing Unit of CID, the Registry of Societies and the Inland Revenue

Column: 989

Authority of Singapore. These are adequate and MCD need not add to the bureaucracy. Nevertheless, we will monitor the situation and put in place measures to improve the situation, if needed.

    Let me now turn to Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon. I share the concerns of the hon. Member on the importance of family values and social cohesion. She has stated her case passionately and comprehensively. I think I have addressed her concerns on the need to strengthen family ties and values in my speech yesterday. With increasing and competing pressures on the family, the inculcation of family values is crucial for the preservation of the family as the basic building block of our society. We have Dr Ngiam Tee Liang from the NUS to chair a committee to promote Singapore's family values. It works in close collaboration with social service agencies, civic groups, schools, the private sector and the unions. Dr Ngiam is also a member of the Committee on the Family chaired by Mr Noel Hon, which is being appointed this month, to look into strategic issues affecting the well-being of the family.

    I turn now to questions from Dr Lily Neo and Mr Ang Mong Seng. I will take the questions by both Members together. They asked on MCD's strategy to prepare for an aging population, which I have already informed the House in broad terms in my opening speech yesterday. I would like to thank both Members for sharing their comments, especially to Dr Neo for sharing her vision on elder care. We want our senior citizens to be healthy, active and secure. We must formulate the right elderly policies, develop elderly friendly infrastructure and change the mindset of the elderly as well as that of the younger Singaporeans towards the elderly.

    A key strategy of MCD is therefore to strengthen public education programmes on aging. We want Singaporeans to value the elderly as a resource and to see growing older as a time for further development, learning and continuing contribution to society. I agree with Dr Neo's point that building a home environment

Column: 990

that is safe and elderly friendly should be encouraged. Mr Ang Mong Seng has also noted that not all senior citizens can afford studio apartments. The IMC's review of housing for the elderly will address concerns of both Members.

    Members might like to know that MCD and HDB started a number of projects to provide elderly friendly features in one-room rental apartment blocks for the elderly. The Senior Activity Centres in these projects provide services to the elderly and serve as focal points for mutual help. They are run by VWOs and are very much like the Centre of Activity for Retired Elderly (CARE) that Dr Lily Neo mentioned. MCD will look into how our present concept of Senior Activity Centres can be improved or even expanded to better meet the needs of the well elderly. MCD will ensure a coordinated effort amongst voluntary care groups in the delivery of services. Three regional Community Care Networks and a National Geriatric Coordinating Committee, spearheaded by the NCSS and MOH respectively, are working towards a network of comprehensive and coordinated services at the local level, as well as to share best practices.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng suggested that the Elderly Development Division of my Ministry should work closely with the grassroots organisations in implementing services and programmes for the elderly which are practical and close to the ground. I share his view. The Division will indeed work closely with PA and CDCs to explore how the grassroots organisations can play a bigger role in these areas. I agree with Mr Ang's comment on the need to reskill older workers in order to keep up with the pace of technological change. We will have to look into this issue more closely.

    On the issue of elderly abuse which was raised by Dr Neo yesterday, I wish to assure the Member that the Ministry does not condone all forms of family violence, including abuse of the elderly. Legislative and non-legislative measures have been put in place to manage and curb family violence and we will monitor the situation

Column: 991

and will continue to improve on these measures, if necessary.
12.45 pm

    The amendments to the Women's Charter in 1996 both enhanced and extended protection to elderly victims of family violence. We also implemented a national networking system for managing family violence on 1st July 1996. This system is a coordinated multi-disciplinary approach for the management of family violence cases involving the MCD, the Police, hospitals, the Family Court, social service agencies and the crisis shelters. Any victim who seeks assistance will be informed of all the other services available to him or her. And he or she will be advised on how to receive protection, counselling and shelter. Public education materials have been distributed to polyclinics, hospitals, NPPs, FSCs and other social service agencies to increase awareness of family violence and to inform them of what they can do about it.

    Sir, the issue of elderly abuse is complex. There are cases where children may not intentionally abuse their parents but neglect their basic needs. Many families may also not know how to cope with the elderly who are suffering from medical problems such as senile dementia. My Ministry produced two video tapes on elderly care entitled "Caring by Elderly Spouses" - this was last year - and "Caring by the Sandwich Generation" also produced last year. Certainly, more can be done to support and educate care givers on the elderly.

    My Ministry will develop a protocol on the reporting and management of elder abuse this year. This project is also intended to educate the general public and persons who are likely to come into frequent contact with elderly persons on how to identify signs of elder abuse and to help such abused persons obtain assistance and protection.

    I now come to the amendment by Dr Ho Tat Kin asking for further developments on the Inter-Ministerial Committee (IMC)

Column: 992

on the aging population. In my statement yesterday, I had briefly touched on the role of the IMC on the aged. The IMC has been meeting monthly. It has been briefed by various Ministries, statutory boards, non-Government organisations and the voluntary welfare organisations as well, to familiarise itself with the various policies, programmes and issues associated with an aging population. Work groups are now being formed to conduct in-depth reviews in the various areas of concern, eg, employment, employability, financial security, housing and social integration.

    I agree with Dr Ho that we must encourage the habit and create opportunities for continuing education and life-long learning for older Singaporeans. This is key to employability, financial security as well as personal enrichment in later years. He suggested setting up a dedicated university for senior citizens. Presently, senior citizens who wish to pursue higher education already have the opportunity to do so at some existing institutions of higher learning, such as our Open University. One way is for the university to tailor its programmes to meet the needs and aspirations of older people. In any case, I will pass on this suggestion to the IMC to consider.

    Sir, my Parliamentary Secretary will now reply to two questions related to the People's Association.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development (Mr Chan Soo Sen): Sir, on behalf of my Minister, allow me to address two of the amendments related to the People's Association. One is by Mr Low Thia Khiang on voluntary organisations and social workers, and the other is by Mr Ang Mong Seng on community bonding. Since both amendments were raised in Mandarin, allow me to reply in Mandarin as well.

    (In Mandarin):

    Mr Ang Mong Seng said that grassroots organisations have made great efforts in uniting our nation, and have contributed greatly to our nation building and national unity. I fully agree with him. Mr Ang has

Column: 993

also mooted the idea of a "Unity Circle". The 12 Cs that he mentioned yesterday are actually related to unity cycle. We look forward to hearing more specific recommendations from him on how to put this idea into practice.

    He suggested that there should be National Day Observance ceremonies at every community club or community centre. I agree with him and I will urge all the CCs to take this into consideration. He has also recommended that at the National Day Parade, we should have some display of our defence facilities to show our people our defence readiness. The People's Association will bring up this matter with the National Day Parade Committee for its consideration.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang mentioned that the voluntary social workers are not enjoying due recognition in our society, and that they have no status. He commented that our grassroots organisations have a lot of benefits, and he asked whether these grassroots organisations enjoy all these benefits because they are actually serving the PAP, and not the community. .

    Let us talk about the last point that he raised. In fact, this is not the first time that he has brought up the matter. I must reiterate that the grassroots organisations serve the community and not the PAP. In fact, we make it a point that activities of the PAP are kept clearly distinct from community activities. For example, the PAP is not allowed to carry out any activities in the community centres, because the community centres are run by community organisations. If he feels that the grassroots leaders are getting the benefits because they serve the PAP, he is wrong. As Mr Ang Mong Seng has said, the grassroots organisations have contributed greatly in uniting our nation and in enhancing our social cohesiveness. Over the past 30 years, they have observed the main objectives of uniting our nation and enhancing cohesiveness among our people. Our society has undergone great changes in the past 30 years. The grassroots organisations are able to adjust themselves and to continue being relevant to our nation. Therefore, we feel that the grassroots organisations

Column: 994

deserve the rewards or recognition that they are getting today. In some grassroots organisations, the volunteer workers have dedicated the best time of their lives to community service. I think this is indeed very praiseworthy.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang also mentioned that our voluntary social workers need to be given better rewards and recognition in our society, and he is concerned about the welfare of the social workers. I fully agree with him on this point. I think all of us in this House will also agree with him on this. Yesterday, my Minister mentioned that MCD will set up an inter-Ministry agency to facilitate volunteerism. One of the main objectives of this agency is to do a comprehensive overall review on how to provide better rewards and recognition for these voluntary social workers. If anyone has any suggestion, please let me know and I will commit it to this agency for consideration. I think we should also attach more importance to volunteerism. I hope that by the 21st century we will have more volunteer social workers coming forward to serve our nation.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Sir, a clarification from the Parliamentary Secretary. When doing voluntary work, sometimes our VWOs exceed the time of their parking coupons and they were summoned for that. Why can we not provide VWOs who drive the convenience of free parking in our HDB or URA car parks?

    Just now, the Parliamentary Secretary said that the work of the PAP and the grassroots organisations is not related. I would like him to state categorically how do the PAP workers and the grassroots workers disassociate themselves during the general elections.

    Mr Chan Soo Sen(In Mandarin): Sir, regarding the parking problem, as I have said just now, we can let the proposed agency look into it. Not all volunteer workers drive. So we will see whether something can be done about it. Let the agency look into the matter and see what is the outcome.

Column: 995



    As for the general elections, grassroots organisations do not participate in PAP's election work. If they have participated, that is because they themselves are PAP members. We do not deny that there are some members of grassroots organisations who are PAP members. If they help the PAP in the election work, they are working in their capacity as PAP members. They are not helping the PAP in their capacity as grassroots workers. There is no association in the first place, so, therefore there is no question of dissociation.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, I would like to speak on the need for a review of public assistance rates. I have two issues of concern to raise. First, public assistance rates for the poor have not been revised for the past few years. The cost of living has been very tight for the unsupported poor. Their source of assistance has thinned out, because of the current economic problems. There are less people providing the necessary support. In the light of this, there is a need to see what the Ministry of Community Development would be able to do in revising the public assistance rates.

    The other issue that I would like to raise is a more pressing problem. This is in connection with the unskilled and unsupported retrenched workers. There are quite a number of them that I have been noticing this trend in the meet-the-people sessions and other community organisations. I feel that this group, for the first time, have run into difficulties. For many years since the last recession or even close to the 1950s, this phenomenon has not come about. The problems of older, unskilled retrenched workers probably need closer attention, because many of them have families. Some of them are in their late 40s and below 50, who have found great difficulty in getting employment over a period. Because, in the first place, they are unskilled and that many of the companies that they are working with are relocating to other economies.

Column: 996


1.00 pm

    Sir, in the short term, there is a need for PA rules to be made flexible to provide temporary financial assistance for this group of retrenched older workers. Would MCD be prepared to look into helping these unemployed retrenched workers and their families? Perhaps may I suggest that a social support fund be made available to provide temporary assistance to them for a period of time so that they would be able to get through their difficulties until they find alternative employment through further training. This would be one solution to a problem like this.

    Sir, on a longer term measure, this issue is likely to recur when we run into another economic problem in future. It is therefore necessary for MCD, the Ministry of Manpower and Singapore Employers' Federation to work out a scheme to follow through retrenched workers, particularly older retrenched workers, who are unlikely to find employment, or would have difficulty in finding employment. This group of people would perhaps require closer attention of the various Ministries concerned, including NTUC, which together with its members could work on a concerted effort to tackle the problems of these older workers. I would like to find out from the Minister what are the plans it has to deal with these special problems.

    Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, MCD reviews the public assistance given to the poor and needy once every two years. I believe, this year, public assistance will be up for review also. I would like to ask what adjustments will be made to increase the amount given out under the Public Assistance Scheme.

    With more than 28,000 being retrenched last year, I understand not all those who lost their jobs received retrenchment benefits. The criteria for Public Assistance Scheme which till now still help only the very poor need to be relaxed. Older retrenched workers, particularly those with outdated skills and with families to support will need temporary help to tide

Column: 997

them over prolonged unemployment, especially during this economic crisis.

    Sir, may I ask what schemes will be put in place to provide temporary assistance to those who have been out of the job market for some time, especially those who have exhausted their savings?

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, in the course of my constituency work, I have come across many families who are in need of financial assistance. Very often, these people are in a desperate situation, either because they have lost their jobs, their loved ones have passed away or they have been deserted by their spouses. Invariably, where these families have children, it is often the children who suffer as a consequence. These residents have the gumption to come to my assistance or the assistance of my CCC. Invariably, in the course of the interview, I learn that besides getting in touch with the grassroots organisations, many of these people who need financial assistance or public assistance are not aware of the many schemes that are available which can be of help during these difficult times. These public assistance schemes may include, for example, the Small Families Improvement Scheme, the CCC Welfare and Education Committee's Scholarships and Bursaries, the CDC Assistance Scheme, to name a few.

    What about those who never thought of seeking assistance from the MP or the grassroots organisations? How can we effectively reach out to them and extend the assistance provided by these public assistance schemes? For them, they operate in a world of ignorance, and unless we reach out to them, it may be that they would never be able to take advantage of these public assistance schemes that are available. Additionally, it could also be that many of these people are just too shy to come forward to seek the assistance of the Government, or the voluntary welfare organisations in respect of these public assistance schemes. The fact that for many of these people in need of financial assistance, they need to be told of the public assistance schemes, either through the grassroots organisations or through the voluntary welfare

Column: 998

organisations, tells us that these schemes are not very widely known or well publicised. If we want to do more for the less fortunate Singaporeans, we should be more proactive rather than reactive. We should, in the first place, take steps to educate Singaporeans on what they can do or who they can turn to in times of need.

    I have seen public information campaign run by the various Ministries, such as the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Health. However, I have yet to see a concerted effort by the Ministry of Community Development in running mass education campaigns through the public media to inform Singaporeans of the public assistance schemes. I am not sure whether MCD's choice in not using the public media to publicise these schemes arises from a reluctance to encourage a perception of Singapore as a welfare state. Personally, I do not think using the media to publicise the schemes that are available is a step in the direction. On the other hand, using the public media maximises our effort in reaching out to those who are genuinely in need of assistance and thus helps us to care for them in a way which we, as Singaporeans, should. Such effort by the Ministry of Community Development is important, particularly during this difficult time when more people are unemployed than before. I would like to ask the Minister whether more effort can be made by the Ministry to promote awareness among Singaporeans on the various programmes and assistance that Singaporeans can turn to for help, if necessary.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Sir, in the past, some 29,000 workers were retrenched or facing retrenchment. According to a survey, the situation today is that out of every ten job seekers, only four jobs are available. Another survey shows that 50% of the retrenched workers have to wait for nine months before they can get another job. This shows that it is not easy to find alternative jobs nowadays.

    32% of the workers will be unemployed for more than nine months. Being

Column: 999

unemployed for nine months is a long period. These people depend on their past savings to tide them over the difficult times. After the nine months, I believe their savings would have been exhausted. These people would probably have to look to the Government agencies and other charitable organisations for help. We know that the Singapore Government's Public Assistance Scheme is quite stringent in its allocation of funds. The amount allocated is barely enough to meet the basic living expenses. Those who are in receipt of this assistance cannot have other sources of income. I would like the Minister to tell us whether there is an increase in the number of people who have applied for public assistance during the past one year. For those who have been unemployed for more than nine months, will the Government be more liberal and sympathetic towards them so that they can receive public assistance? I am making these suggestions because those who are receiving public assistance cannot depend on it for a living for long. As soon as they find a job, they would not ask for public assistance.

    On the other hand, the amount they receive in the form of public assistance is barely enough to meet the basic living expenses, and therefore the recipients' standard of living and quality of life have been affected Their family members may be very young. Therefore, a drop in the quality of life would affect their health. Can the Government consider allowing a public assistance recipient's family members to work part time to help make ends meet?

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): According to the economic crisis monitoring report of a number of clients from Family Service Centres, the people most affected by the current economic downturn were female single parents aged between 36-49 years old and living in 2-room flats. Their problems were primarily difficulties in securing employment after retrenchment, in meeting basic household needs and children's school related expenses. Other

The SAT1, which relies less on content and more on generic reasoning in the verbal and quantitative areas, provides a measure of a person's reasoning ability.
